name: Factory Yards - North Commercial
overview: Factory Yards North Commercial is a purpose-built commercial component within the broader Factory Yards redevelopment in Grand Rapids. The project delivers modern, highly functional space designed to support long-term tenant success while complementing the surrounding residential and commercial activation of the district. The development reflects our focus on durable design, efficient execution, and thoughtful integration into a revitalized historic industrial environment.
investment_thesis: Strategically developed and leased to a publicly traded tenant on a long-term basis, the project provides stable cash flow within a growing Grand Rapids submarket. By combining disciplined development execution, strong market fundamentals, and integration within a larger mixed-use ecosystem, the asset is positioned for predictable income and long-term appreciation.
highlights: Long-term lease to publicly traded national tenant (confidential)
Institutional-quality commercial construction and design
Integrated within Factory Yards mixed-use redevelopment
Strategic Grand Rapids urban infill location
Efficient design supporting tenant operations and long-term value
Built for durability, flexibility, and sustained cash flow

name: Factory Yards - South Commercial
overview: Factory Yards South Commercial reimagines a former 67,000-square-foot industrial building within the broader Factory Yards redevelopment, transforming underutilized manufacturing space into productive, tenant-focused commercial uses. The project blends adaptive reuse with thoughtful modernization, creating amenity-driven space designed to support both residents of the Factory Yards district and the surrounding neighborhood while preserving the historic character of the structure.
investment_thesis: The project unlocks value from otherwise difficult-to-develop industrial space by integrating climate-controlled self-storage as a resident amenity within the broader Factory Yards district. This approach efficiently utilizes non-traditional commercial space while supporting the residential ecosystem, generating stable income and enhancing the overall livability and long-term performance of the mixed-use community.
highlights: 67,000-square-foot adaptive reuse industrial redevelopment
Fitness and lifestyle-oriented commercial tenant opportunities
Climate-controlled indoor self-storage component as resident amenity
Integrated within the broader Factory Yards mixed-use district
Preservation of historic industrial character with modern upgrades
Designed to support long-term operational stability and value creation

name: Factory Yards - Mixed Use
overview: Factory Yards Mixed Use is a large-scale adaptive reuse and ground-up redevelopment transforming a historic industrial campus into a vibrant mixed-use district. The project combines residential, commercial, and public realm components designed to create a durable, walkable neighborhood that honors the site’s industrial heritage while supporting long-term community growth.
investment_thesis: Positioned to benefit from Grand Rapids’ continued urban growth, the project leverages historic preservation incentives, strong housing fundamentals, and disciplined phased execution to create stable cash flow potential and long-term asset appreciation within a revitalizing urban corridor.
highlights: Transformational redevelopment of historic industrial complex
Mixed-use program including residential, retail, and commercial space
Multi-layered capital stack utilizing public and private incentives
Public-private partnership supporting district revitalization
Phased development strategy reducing execution and market risk

name: The Amo
overview: Value-add multifamily repositioning project focused on operational excellence.
investment_thesis: Detroit's multifamily market presents compelling value-add opportunities as the city's revitalization continues.
highlights: Value-add acquisition with below-market rents
Comprehensive renovation program
Operational improvements driving NOI growth
Strong submarket with limited new supply
Proximity to major employers and amenities

name: Avery Place
overview: Located in the heart of Detroit's historic Woodbridge neighborhood, Avery Place is a 23-unit condominium project that was constructed on previously underutilized land purchased from the Detroit Land Bank Authority. This infill project was thoughtfully designed to be harmonious with the neighborhood's existing historic housing stock. The project includes an integrated pocket park, garage parking with electric chargers, walkup unit entries, and large balconies. The project also benefits from a Brownfield tax recapture as well as the Neighborhood Enterprise Zone (NEZ) exemption for homebuyers, significantly reducing the annual property tax expense for homeowners.
investment_thesis: Historic location proximate to Wayne State University, downtown, and Midtown Detroit; significant benefits from Brownfield tax recapture and NEZ.
highlights: Education adjacent location
Historic neighborhood
Significant tax incentives

name: Eastpointe Apartments
overview: Acquired as a 55+ apartment community, the Eastpointe Apartments presented an opportunity to acquire a well-maintained asset with long-term residents with stable monthly incomes. Rents at the time of acquisition were below market and professional management systems were not in place. The value-add process included increasing market rents, re-tenanting a small number of severely delinquent units, and implementing professional property management systems as well as opening the pool of potential tenants to include qualified tenants outside of the previous 55+ mandate.
investment_thesis: Strong location; stable in-place tenant base; well located workforce housing asset; limited deferred maintenance in conjunction with below market rents presents the opportunity for stable cash flow with risk-adjusted upside.
highlights: Strong location
Limited deferred maintenance
Stable tenant base

name: The Kirkwood
overview: The Kirkwood is a 26 unit value-add property located in Detroit's New Center neighborhood, immediately north of Henry Ford Hospital's main campus. The property was acquired in 2021 with significant deferred maintenance and below-market rents. The value-add plan included the renovation of all 26 units as well as interior and exterior common area improvements. This workforce housing asset benefits from the City of Detroit PILOT program, significantly reducing property tax expenses while maintaining affordable rents at or below 80% AMI.
investment_thesis: Healthcare adjacent workforce housing asset benefiting from PILOT tax abatements and proximity to the $2b+ Henry Ford Health campus investment. The property provides well-located affordable housing for hospital employees, students, and healthcare-adjacent workers.
highlights: Significant property tax reduction through the City of Detroit PILOT program
Strong healthcare adjacent location
2- and 3-bedroom units catering to healthcare workers and young families
Proximate to major employment centers and mass transit hubs

name: Garden City Apartments
overview: The Garden City Apartments is a 40-unit workforce housing asset acquired in 2020. At the time of acquisition, rents were significantly below market and professional management systems were not in place. The value-add process included "mark-to-market" rent increases, the implementation of automated and professional management systems, and light unit and common area renovations.
investment_thesis: Strong workforce housing asset located in a stable neighborhood proximate to employment centers and transit corridors. Walk-up units offer a single-family experience within a full-service apartment community, creating strong rental demand. Increasing rents to market rates and reducing operating expenses via streamlined property management processes resulted in increased net operating income and corresponding asset value.
highlights: Strong location near major employment centers and transit corridors
Limited supply of single entry walk-up units supports demand
Common area greenspace, accessibility, and on-site parking adjacent to unit entries

name: 19 Central
overview: 19 Central is strategically positioned between Porter Square and Union Square in the Somerville/Cambridge submarket. Prior ownership had held the asset since its original development in the 1970s, and the property was due for modernization. With strong fundamentals and solid building bones, our value-add program focused on comprehensive interior unit renovations and common area upgrades to reposition the asset for today's renter while preserving its long-term durability.
investment_thesis: Well-located multifamily investment in a high-demand, transit-oriented submarket, executing a targeted value-add strategy through interior renovations, operational enhancements, and disciplined rent growth to drive sustainable cash flow and long-term appreciation.
highlights: 30-unit multifamily property
Significant interior and common area renovation program
Value creation through unit upgrades and market rent increases
Tech-enabled property management implementation
Located between Porter and Union Squares in supply-constrained market

name: Gateways of Plymouth
overview: The Gateways of Plymouth was acquired out of bankruptcy as a development site with horizontal infrastructure in place. Located in the highly desirable corridor between downtown Northville and downtown Plymouth, Michigan, the investment presented the opportunity to leverage previously completed infrastructure to construct for-sale condominiums on an infill site with strong market demand. After completion and sale of the first phase, the remaining lots were sold to a local homebuilder at a significant risk-adjusted profit.
investment_thesis: Excellent location between two thriving suburban downtown markets with high average household incomes; capitalized on then low mortgage interest rates driving buyer demand; in-place infrastructure and entitlements presented the opportunity to quickly construct product to meet strong market demand for residential condominiums in the submarket.
highlights: Excellent suburban downtown-proximate location
In place infrastructure and entitlements
Strong demand for for-sale residential condominium product

name: Milwaukee Condos
overview: The Milwaukee Condominiums project involved the redevelopment of a vacant, blighted, and functionally obsolete building located in Detroit's emerging Milwaukee Junction neighborhood. Purchased from the Wayne County tax foreclosure auction, the building was completely rehabilitated into 8 for-sale condominium units as well as two ground floor commercial spaces. Home to the award winning Kiesling Bar and Milwaukee Caffe coffee shop, the activation of this space was a catalyst for additional neighborhood development, with Milwaukee Junction now home to many diverse and thriving businesses, including a Michelin Star rated restaurant.
investment_thesis: Low acquisition basis; emerging "fringe" location; value creation through thoughtful placemaking.
highlights: Emerging location proximate to major employment and higher education centers
Covered garage parking
Historic adaptive re-use

name: 38 Gibson
overview: Gibson Terrace is located on a picturesque tree-lined street steps from Harvard Square. Nearly a century old, the property has housed generations of professors and students. Our redevelopment focused on honoring its historic character while modernizing the building for long-term functionality and resident comfort.
investment_thesis: Strategic value-add multifamily investment in a premier Cambridge location, combining historic preservation, targeted capital improvements, and operational enhancements to drive durable cash flow and long-term asset appreciation.
highlights: 18-unit multifamily property near Harvard Square
Comprehensive value-add renovation of exterior, units, and common areas
Historic preservation balanced with modernization
Tech-enabled property management implementation
Long-term stewardship approach in a supply-constrained market

name: Northend Portfolio
overview: Purchase from the City of Detroit Land Bank Authority (DLBA), the assets in this portfolio represented an opportunity to acquire a small multifamily portfolio in an emerging neighborhood at an extremely low basis. The project consisted of a full renovation of the interior and exterior of each building, including all plumbing electrical, and mechanical systems, interior buildout, and exterior building elements. The North End neighborhood has experienced rapid growth in rental demand and units were rented at rates significantly above pro forma.
investment_thesis: Low acquisition basis; emerging "fringe" location; tax-favorable basis due to prior land bank ownership; strong rental demand.
highlights: Adjacent to the newly constructed Q-Line light rail system
Proximate to dining, entertainment and employment centers of Midtown and Downtown
Low acquisition basis

name: Trinity Health Grand Rapids
overview: Early-stage mixed-use development partnership evaluating feasibility.
investment_thesis: Healthcare-anchored developments benefit from stable, creditworthy tenants and community support.
highlights: Healthcare system partnership
Early-stage feasibility analysis
Community stakeholder engagement
Mixed-use program evaluation
Long-term ground lease structure under consideration
